Text_without_authors: Significance of speech production error on cross-linguistic processing in Sepedi-English individual with bilingual aphasia : a case series analysis background : bilingual aphasia form a significant part of speech-language pathologists’ (slp) caseload, globally, and specifically in south africa. few tool supporting clinical decision-making are available due to limited understanding of typical and disordered cross-linguistic processing (how the language interact). speech error may provide insight about “hidden” bilingual mechanisms. objective : to determine what speech error can impart about cross-linguistic processing, a well as, associated language and impairment variable in sepedi-english individual with aphasia. method : the case series included six participants, purposively selected from three rehabilitation site in south africa. detailed language and clinical profile were obtained. participant performed a confrontation naming task in their most dominant (mdl) and le dominant language (ldl). response were audio recorded, transcribed, and analyzed for overall accuracy and error type in mdl and ldl; verified by a sepedi-speaking linguist and a qualified slp. result : (1) no statistically significant difference in mdl-ldl naming accuracy were found, supporting recent literature of simultaneous inter-activation of both language and shared word retrieval mechanisms. all type of speech error occurred, and semantic error were produced most frequently and consistently in each participant’s mdl and ldl. (2) language proficiency, language recovery patterns, and aphasia type (broca’s and anomic) and severity (mild and/or moderate) appeared to be more strongly linked to cross-linguistic processing than sepedi-english linguistic difference and age of acquisition of both languages. conclusion : participant with bilingual aphasia may use typical cross-linguistic and word retrieval mechanisms, concurring with current theory of bilingualism. finding are preliminary, warranting investigation of other language tasks, modalities, pairs, and related variables.

African language dictionary for child - a neglected genre  children dictionary are instrumental in establishing a dictionary culture and are the gateway to sustained and informed dictionary use. it is therefore surprising that very little attention is paid to these dictionary in scholarly research. in this article we reflect on the design of two series of dictionary and one free-standing dictionary, all presumably aimed at first-time dictionary users, specifically looking at how selected design element are aligned with the lexicographic need of the target users. we argue that the conceptualization of child dictionary for african-language-speaking child should be a bottom-up process, and that an afrocentric approach, taking the target user frame of reference a the point of departure, is preferable to a eurocentric approach, which often lead to a mismatch between conceptual relationship and linguistic form and function in african language dictionaries. kinderwoordeboeke speel  belangrike rol in die vestiging van  woordeboekkultuur en gee toegangtot volgehoue en kundige woordeboekgebruik. dis is daarom vreemd dat daar min aandag gegeeword aan hierdie tipe woordeboeke in akademiese navorsing. in hierdie artikel besin ons oor dieontwerp van twee woordeboekreekse en  vrystaande woordeboek, wat almal oënskynlik gemik isop beginnergebruikers van woordeboeke. ons kyk spesifiek na die belyning van die ontwerpaspekte van die woordeboeke met die gebruikers se leksikografiese behoeftes. ons duo aan dat diekonseptualisering van kinderwoordeboeke vir sprekers van afrikatale op grondvlak behoort tebegin, en dat  afrosentriese benadering verkieslik is bo  eurosentriese benadering. laasgenoemde benadering lei dikwels tot  mispassing tussen konseptuele verhoudings, en linguistiesevorm en funksie in afrikataalwoordeboeke.

A corpus-driven study of the expression of necessity in Luganda (Bantu, JE15) this article report on the analysis of three major marker of necessity in luganda, i.e. the modal auxiliary -téekw- and -lina and the verbal prefix -andi-. on the basis a 4-million-word corpus it is argued that, overall, the auxiliary -téekw- is more established a a necessity marker, a it is involved in the expression of all necessity subcategories except participant-inherent dynamic necessity. the auxiliary -lina is le semantically diversified, expressing only participant-imposed, situational and deontic necessity, while the verbal prefix -andi- express only deontic necessity. a comparison of corpus data with data from older literature on luganda further show that the objective category of participant-inherent dynamic necessity, which is not associated with any of the three marker described, is perhaps expressed by less-grammaticalised forms. these form are also, together with other grammaticalised form that have increasingly become rare, assumed to be part of the device that could have been responsible for expressing necessity in earlier stage of the language, given that the three marker described in this research have only begun to meaningfully express necessity since the second half of the 20th century.

Determining a Zulu core vocabulary for child who use augmentative and alternative communication vocabulary selection is an important aspect to consider when designing augmentative and alternative communication (aac) system for child who have not yet developed conventional literacy skills. aac team member have used core vocabulary list (representing word most commonly and frequently used by speaker of a natural language) a a resource to assist in this process. to date, there are no core vocabulary list for zulu. therefore, the aim of this study wa to identify the vocabulary most frequently and commonly used by zulu-speaking preschool children, in order to inform vocabulary selection for peer who use aac. communication sample from 6 zulu-speaking participant without disability were collected during regular preschool activities. analysis were conducted both by orthographic word and by morphological analysis of formatives. due to the linguistic and orthographic structure of zulu, an analysis by formative wa found to be more useful to determine a core vocabulary. the number of different formative used, frequency of use, and commonality of use among the participant were identified. a total of 213 core formative were identified; core formative related to language structure were used more frequently than those that related to lexical content. the characteristic of this zulu core vocabulary were consistent with those of core vocabulary established in other languages. implication for the design of zulu aac system are discussed.

The relationship between dictionary look-up frequency and corpus frequency revisited : a log-file analysis of a decade of user interaction with a Swahili-English dictionary in an earlier publication it wa claimed that there is no useful relationship between swahili-english dictionary look-up frequency and the occurrence frequency for the same wordforms in swahili-english corpora, at least not beyond the top few thousand wordforms. this result wa challenged using data for german by a different team of researcher using an improved methodology. in the present article the original swahili-english data is revisited, using ten years’ worth of it rather than just two, and using the improved methodology. we conclude that there is indeed a positive relationship. in addition, we show that online dictionary look-up behaviour is remarkably similar across languages, even when, a in our case, one is dealing with language from very dissimilar language families. furthermore, online dictionary turn out to have minimum look-up success rates, below which they simply cannot go. these minimum are language-sensitive and vary depending on the regularity of the searched-for entries, but are otherwise constant no matter the size of randomly sampled dictionaries. corpus-informed sampling always improves on any random method. lastly, from the point of view of the graphical user interface, we argue that the average user of an online bilingual dictionary is better served with a single search box, rather than separate search box for each dictionary side.

Resurrecting the “black archives”: Revisiting benedict wallet vilakazi with a focus on the utility and meaning of African language and literature in higher education although viewed (and dismissed) by many a primarily a tool for communication, language (and literature) cannot be understood only in relation to what it communicates. a study of how it is shaped uncovers the social force that provide it broad and complex template in the act of reading and writing. this article focus on the utility and meaning of african language and literature in higher education, with benedict wallet vilakazi’s (1906–1947) poetry at the centre. it argues how, by resurrecting “black archives”, in this article epitomised by revisiting the work of one iconic writer and scholar, vilakazi, we could give further impetus to the prospect of intellectual effort in african languages. in this context, the article upholds the value and meaning of this scholar while offering perspective on the saliency of his work for inter alia the meaning and location of african language and literature with regard to epistemic diversity, the “transformation” of curricula, tradition versus modernity, gender, the meaning of identity, and the broader humanist project. in essence, therefore, the article suggests that in an academic context, african language and literature require a serious engagement with the “implied reader”, “the native subject” and consequently necessitates greater troubling, unsettling in the way we teach, the way we write, and the way we read. it suggests that act of rereading (albeit preliminary) are an important intervention in the project of the intellectualisation of our discipline.

An overview of digital lexicography and direction for it future : an interview with Gilles-Maurice de Schryver  in this contribution rove chishman and bruna da silva present questionsto the president of the european association for lexicography, gilles-maurice deschryver. in answering, g-m de schryver call a spade a spade: no, there is no theoryof lexicography, but yes, there is a future for lexicographers. for that future to be bright,lexicographers will have to join hand with the big data companies, and accept that theirinvaluable input will be all but invisible to the users. artificial intelligence componentswill have to be used in earnest, so that ‘searches’ (not ‘look-ups’!) will instantly lead tocontext-sensitive answers. browsing lexical data only start from these answer and proceedsfrom there in two- (and why not three-) dimensional multimedia spaces. to achievethis, g-m de schryver point to the most promising research idea at present, a well asthe top team involved in digital dictionary user research. nesta contribuição, rove chishman e bruna da silva apresentam perguntasao presidente da associação europeia de lexicografia, gilles-maurice deschryver. ao responder, g-m de schryver vai direto ao ponto: não, não há teoria dalexicografia, mas, sim, há um futuro para o lexicógrafos. para que esse futuro sejabrilhante, o lexicógrafos terão de tornar-se aliados da empresas que lidam comgrandes quantidades de dado e aceitar que a contribuição inestimável que oferecemserá praticamente invisível para o usuários. o componentes da inteligência artificialterão de ser usados com seriedade para que a ‘buscas’ (como em ferramentasde busca; não a ‘consultas’, como em dicionários impressos) instantaneamente conduzamo usuário a respostas sensíveis ao contexto. a navegação por dado lexicaisapenas começa com essas respostas e prossegue a partir daí por e para espaços multimídiabi- (e por que não tri-?) dimensionais. para que isso seja alcançado, g-m deschryver aponta a ideias de pesquisa mais promissoras atualmente, bem como asprincipais equipes envolvidas na pesquisa sobre usuários de dicionários digitais.

Corpus-driven Bantu lexicography Part 3 : Mapping meaning onto use in Lusoga  this article is the third instalment in a trilogy of study that deal with corpus-driven bantu lexicography a applied to lusoga. having dealt with corpus-building in part 1, and macro-structural aspect in part 2, we now focus on the microstructure of a dictionary and in particular on the concept of mapping meaning onto use. the starting point is patrick hank book chapter by the same title, which we transpose to a study of the high-frequent motion verb -v- in lusoga. our detailed analysis is a much practical a it is methodological. olupapula luno n'olwokusatu mu nteeko y'okulaga omusomo gw'omutengeso gw'eitu ogukozesebwa mu namawanika w'ennimi dha bantu ogulaga omulimu ogw'akolebwa ku lusoga. oluvainhuma lw'okwandhula engeli eitu ly'olusoga mu kitundu 1 n'omuteeko gw'omutindiigo ogusinziilwaku okuzimba olukala lwa namungi w'ebigambowazo mu kitundu 2, buti eisila liize ku kulaga ngeli amakulu g'ebigambo ye gakwanaganizibwa n'enkozesa. omusingi gw'eisomo elilagibwa mu kitundu kino gw'ateebwawo patrick hanks. ensonga enkulu dhe yataaku eisila dhilondoolebwa okusinziila ku kigelo kya namungi w'ennhingizo entabaazi (o)ku.v.a. olupapula luno lugelaagelania engeli ennhingizo eno bwe yaingizibwa mu eiwanika ly'olusoga elitaasinziililwa ku itu lya bigambo n'engeli gye yandibaile esengekebwa singa eitu n'ebigelo by'emiwendo egilagibwamu byali bikozeseibwa. eby'asoboka n'ebitaasoboka bigelaagelanhizibwa n'ebigendelelwa by'omusingi gw'eisomo ly'eitu lya namawanika mu mpandiika y'amawanika.

Corpus-driven Bantu lexicography Part 2 : Lemmatisation and ruler for Lusoga this article is the second in a trilogy that deal with corpus-driven bantu lexicogra-phy, which is illustrated for lusoga. the focus here is on the macrostructure and in particular on the building of a lemmatised frequency list directly within a dictionary-writing system. the pro-gramming code for the part of the lemmatisation that may be automated is included a addenda. a second focus is on the embedded part-of-speech and alphabetical rulers, for which it is shown how these may be used to plan the actual compilation of the dictionary entries.

Corpus-driven Bantu lexicography Part 1 : Organic corpus building for Lusoga  this article is the first in a trilogy that deal with corpus-driven bantu lexicography, which is illustrated for lusoga. the focus here is on the building of a so-called 'organic corpus' from scratch, while the next two instalment will deal with the use of that corpus on the macro-structural and microstructural levels, respectively. not many detailed description of corpus-building effort exist for bantu languages, so each and every step is discussed in detail, paying particular attention to the parameter that have to be taken into account, while not losing sight of the need to log the metadata either. olupapula luno n'olusooka ku isatu edhinaayogela ku musomo gw'omutengeso gw'eitu ogukozesebwa mu namawanika w'ennimi dha bantu nga gulaga omulimu ogw'akolebwa ku lusoga. mu lupapula luno, eisila lili ku nzimba ya itu namukyukilo okuva ku ntandiiko. ebitundu ebinaaba mu lupapula olw'okubili n'olw'okusatu biidha kugema ku nkozesa ya itu lino ku isa ly'omutindiigo ogw'ebizimbibwa mu mutegeko n'eisa elilaga eitu lino mu mwoleko ogw'azimbibwa mu mutindiigo n'engeli omusingi ogulimu bwe gulagibwa mu iwanika. mu nnimi dha bantu, emilimu egilaga omusingi guno tigitela kuwandiikibwaku mu butongole okusobola okumanhisa abo abayinza okuba nga bagasibwa. kale buli kitundu ekiteesebwaku mu nnambika eli mu mpapula eisatu dhino kitoolayo buli kanhomelo ka bukodyo n'emitendela egy'agobelebwa ela gy'akozesebwa mu kusenvula omulimu gw'okuzimba omutimbo gw'ekyebungo ky'olulimi olusoga gwonagwona.

Diponagalo tša epiki ya Sesotho sa Leboa  serudu le groenewald ke borateori ba babedi bao ba ilego ba leka go laetša thulaganyo ya epiki ya sesotho sa leboa. le ge go le bjalo, borateori ba ba a fapana ge ba hlaloša dikgopolo tša epiki, seretotumišo, seretokanegelo le thetogale. serudu, o gatelela gore thetogale le thetokanegelo di a swana, mola groenewald yena a bolela gore le ge di tswalana, ga di swane ka gobane thetogale e lebane le (a) bophelo goba lefase ka bophara le (b) mongwalelo woo o phagamego, mola thetokanegelo e lebane le batho/bophelo bjoo bo tlwaelegilego gammogo le mathata a bona ao a tlwaelegilego go tikologo yeo e itšego moo go yona baanegwa, ditiragalo le lefelo di kgathago tema ye bohlokwa. ka go realo, dipolelo tša mohuta wo tša go thulana, di ka hlola tlhakahlakano ge dikgopolo tša go swana le tše di hlalošwa. ka fao nyakišišo ye e tla lebelela dipharologantšho tša epiki ya sesotho sa leboa ka go di nepiša le sebilwane (1961), leduleputswa (1953), ga se ya lešaka le (1973) le maletsoge (1985) go lebeletšwe mehlala le tirišo go tšwa diretong tša mohuta wo. serudu and groenewald are two theorist who have attempted to indicate the structure of the sesotho sa leboa epic narrative. however, in their definition of the concept epic narrative, praise poetry, narrative poetry and heroic poetry they differ from each other. serudu, in his argument, asserts that epic poetry and epic narrative are synonymous, while groenewald argues that they are related to each other, but they are not synonyms, because epic narrative focus on (a) life or the world a a whole and (b) a style that is elevated, while heroic poetry is aimed at ordinary people/life and their ordinary problem in a certain environment wherein characters, event and milieu play a significant role. a a result, such conflicting statement may cause confusion when concept such a these are under discussion. this study will focus on the characteristic feature of sesotho sa leboa epic poetry by aligning them to sebilwane (1961), leduleputswa (1953), ga se ya lešaka le (1973) and maletsoge (1985) focusing on the example and application from these poems.

Songs by female diviner initiate from Zwelibomvu in KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa : a response to patriarchal abuse in their society indigenous society that are steeped in patriarchy have various avenue through which they deal with the abuse characteristic of relation in some of these communities. one such route is song which allow woman to voice that which, bound by societal expectations, they would not normally be able to say. this article present the case of several young female diviner initiate in zwelibomvu, kwazulu-natal who have experienced different form of abuse. these initiates, under the guise of being possessed and through song that are supported by personal-experience narratives, open up about the ordeal they suffer under patriarchal power in their families.

Reconstructing the origin of the Luganda (JE15) modal auxiliary -sóból- and -yînz- : a historical-comparative study across the West Nyanza Bantu cluster in this article, a comparison is made of the expression of possibility in west nyanza bantu language in order to reconstruct the origin of luganda’s two most frequent possibility markers, viz. the near-synonymous auxiliary -sóból- and -yînz-. earlier luganda diachronic corpus-driven analysis showed that -yînz- ha been involved in expressing all possibility category since the 1890s, which is when luganda wa first reduced to writing, while -sóból- acquired deontic possibility a a meaning only in the 1950s. although this would suggest that -yînz- is the possibility marker with the greatest time depth in luganda and across west nyanza, with -sóból- a relative newcomer, the comparative data which is presented in this article indicates the opposite. it is shown that while -yînz- only exists in some west nyanza language (namely in the subgroup which includes luganda, lusoga and lugwere), -sóból- is attested in all west nyanza language a well a in other great lake bantu language outside west nyanza. the fact that the cognate of -sóból- in all great lake bantu language carry a dynamic modal meaning ‘be able’ suggests that it modal usage is older in any of the individual language considered here than what language-internal luganda data seems to suggest.

Language learning application for Sepedi : a user experience study being a multilingual country rich in culture and diversity, south africa ha resident who use a variety of the 11 official language for daily communication. multilingual communication occurs especially in hospital and clinics. people visiting healthcare facility often struggle to locate a health professional that share the same language or even a language which is similar to their own and thus intelligible to them. the research which is reported on here aimed to assist the university of pretoria in it endeavour to address this situation by teaching student an additional language. this wa done by providing three custom-designed, mobile-assisted sepedi language learning application to student from the faculty of health science enrolled for the sepedi language module, sepedi for beginners. the application were specifically designed to assist student with the acquisition of vocabulary related to healthcare. the student used the application a supplementary tool and gave feedback through a questionnaire, to establish whether the student perceived the mobile application to be useful a a supplement to the course material and whether they had a clear preference for a specific application. the result of this study show a positive response to the applications, including strong preference expressed by the participants.

The diachronic semantics of the dissociative past completive construction in the Kikongo language cluster (Bantu) this article aim to give a semantic study of the reflex of one specifictense/aspect form, namely the so-called *-a-b-a construction, in a cluster of about40-odd kikongo language variety spoken in a wide area around the mouth of thecongo river in central africa. we first present a detailed analysis of the multipleuses of these cognate construction at sentence level, in order to arrive at a formaland semantic reconstruction for the most recent common ancestor of the kikongolanguage cluster, namely proto-kikongo. the analysis departs from the overallaspectual meaning of the linguistic expression in which the tense-aspect constructionis used. therefore, we also take into consideration the contribution of differentaspectual tiers, such a lexical and grammatical aspect, adverbial and taxi constructions.through the discussion of themultiple us of the -a-b-a construction,weargue that it overall meaning is complex, combining both temporal and aspectualsemantics. it is furthermore shown that a lexical-aspect distinction between statesof-affairs with transitional versus non-transitional temporal structure is crucial inorder to understand the various us of the -a-b-a construction. methodologically, the formal and semantic reconstruction to proto-kikongo are based on a thoroughcomparison of a multitude of existing data sources, some of which several centuriesold, a well a original fieldwork. this bottom-up approach ha rarely been pursuedover the past half century in bantu grammatical reconstructions.

Tladi wa Dikgati : Sengwalo sa phatose [‘pathos’]  ka lebaka la gore ditiragalo tša phatose di fela di hlakahlakanywa bobading le bosekaseking bja masetlapelo, taodišwane ye e yo ahlaahla kanegelo ya phatose ge e nepiša mohuta wa sengwalo sa kwešišano sa go lebana le phatose. bjale ditiragalo tša phatose di tlo hlalošwa ge di lebane le kwelobohloko le manyami a magolo a go nyalana le lehu la molwantšhwa yoo karolo ya setšhaba le mmadi ba ikgwerantšego le yena. moanegwa yoo o welwa ke matshwenyego a magolo ka kudu go feta moanegwagolo wa masetlapelo.tlhalošo ya ditiragalo tša sengwalo sa phatose, e yo kgonthišwa ka go sekaseka kanegelo ya go ngwalwa ke phatudi ka ngwaga wa 1964 gore go tle go gatelelwe tharollo ya kgakanego le tlabego tšeo di felago di rotoša hlogo ya go lebana le go ba gona ga kwelobohloko dingwalong tša mohuta wo wa masetlapelo le phatose. nyakišišo e yo kgonthiša ge tlhokofalo ya tladi (moanegwathwadi wa phatose) e tsoša tlabego le kgakanego ka tsela ya kwelobohloko ye kgolo go setšhaba. narratives of pathos are often confused with tragic narratives. this article analysis a novel of pathos, phatudi novella tladi wa dikgati a a moral narrative. pathos is explained in term of how it evokes pity for the protagonist pain, which culminates in the death of the main character, who is a loyal and much appreciated member of society and ha captured the esteem of the readers.the main character in a narrative of pathos experience serious problem which differ from those experienced by the main character of tragic narratives. a detailed explanation of pathos is given in an analysis of phatudi novella in order to solve the confusion that emanates from the pity shown by reader of the two type of narrative (tragic narrative and narrative of pathos). the discussion focus on the death of the protagonist of pathos.

Direct user guidance in e-dictionaries for text production and text reception — the verbal relative in Sepedi a a case study  this article introduces a prototype of a writing (and learning) assistant for verbal relative clause of the african language sepedi, accessible from within a dictionary or from a word processor. it is an example of how a user support tool for complicated grammatical structure in a scarcely resourced language can be compiled. we describe a dynamic light-weight tool aimed at combining user-knowledge with text production support, i.e., user-involved interactive text production of the complicated verbal relative in sepedi. in this article, the focus is on access in a dictionary use situation. although the tool is intended a a writing assistant to support user in text production; it also satisfies text reception and cognitive needs, but it focus is on solving text production issue related with the interaction between lexical item and complex grammatical structure in the african (bantu) language and for learning by user and/or training user in this interaction. hierdie artikel stel  prototipe van  skryf- en (leer)hulpmiddel bekend vir werkwoordrelatiewe konstruksies in die afrikataal sepedi, wat vanuit  woordeboek of  woordverwerker toeganklik is. dit dien a voorbeeld van hoe  gebruikershulpmiddel vir ingewikkelde grammatikale strukture in  hulpbronbeperkte taal saamgestel kan word. ons beskryf  dinamiese liggewig hulpmiddel wat gemik is op die kombinering van gebruikerskennis met teksproduksie-ondersteuning, dit wil sê, gebruikersbetrokkenheid by interaktiewe teksproduksie van die ingewikkelde werkwoordrelatiewe in sepedi. in hierdie artikel is die fokus op toegang tydens  woordeboekgebruiksituasie. hoewel die werktuig bedoel is a  skryfhulpmiddel om gebruikers in die produksie van teks te ondersteun, voldoen dit ook aan teksresepsie- en kognitiewe behoeftes. die fokus is egter op die oplossing van teksproduksiekwessies wat verband hou met die interaksie tussen leksikale item en komplekse grammatikale strukture in die afrikatale asook op die aanleer van taal deur gebruikers en/of die opleiding van gebruikers in hierdie interaksie.

Afrikataalleksikografie : gister, vandag en more  hierdie artikel het ten doel om  perspektief te bied op afrikataalleksikografie se reaksie op ontwikkelings in die internasionale leksikografiepraktyk met betrekking tot nuwe tendense en veranderinge wat hoofsaaklik deur die elektroniese era teweeg gebring word. die ont-wikkeling van die afrikataalleksikografie sal met dié van hoofsaaklik engelse papier- en elektro-niese woordeboeke vergelyk word. drie tydperke van leksikografiese ontwikkeling word onder-skei. daar word geargumenteer dat die algehele prentjie vir die ontwikkeling van afrikataalleksi-kografie minder gunstig is a dié van engels en tale soos duits en frans. die fokus is op die beskik-baarheid van woordeboeke, leksikografiese gehalte, die gebruik van nuwe beskikbare rekenaarteg-nologieë en die gebruik van inligtingsbronne van die inligtingsera. daar word tot die gevolgtrek-king gekom dat die leksikografiepraktyk in die afrikatale in die meeste gevalle nie tred hou met internasionale ontwikkelings in die leksikografie nie en dat die aantal uitdagings vir dié tale toege-neem het. ten slotte word  aantal stukragte geïdentifiseer wat ten goede kan meewerk om die kwaliteit van afrikataalwoordeboeke te verbeter. this article aim to give a perspective on african language lexicography response to develop-ments in international lexicographic practice in relation to new trend and change mainly brought about by the electronic era. the development of african language lexicography will be compared to that of mainly english paper and electronic dictionaries. three period of lexicographic devel-opment are distinguished. it will be argued that the overall picture for the development of african language lexicography compare le favourably to that of english and language such a german and french. the focus will be on the availability of dictionaries, lexicographic quality, use of new computer technology and the use of information source made available by the information era. it will be concluded that in most instance african language lexicography is not keeping up with international development in lexicography and that the number of challenge for these language ha increased. finally a number of positive factor will be identified which could contribute to the improvement of the quality of dictionary for african languages.

From conditionality to modality in Luganda (Bantu, JE15) : a synchronic and diachronic corpus analysis of the verbal prefix -andi- this article offer a synchronic and diachronic analysis of the use and meaning of the verbal prefix -andi- in the great lake bantu language luganda (je15). on the basis of a text corpus of 4 million tokens, we show that the prefix, commonly described a a conditional marker, is primarily involved in the expression of modal meanings, specifically deontic necessity and epistemic possibility. our thirteen-decade diachronic corpus analysis show that there is a relationship between the increased use of -andi- outside syntactically complex conditional constructions, i.e. those having both a protasis and an apodosis, and an increase in it expression of modal meanings. moreover, a reduction in the use of -andi- in complex conditional construction go hand in hand with a reduction in it expression of conditional meanings. it is further revealed that contrary to the common cross-linguistic tendency to rely on modality a a source for conditionality, the conditional meaning of -andi- is not post-modal. instead it wa primarily a conditional marker, which subsequently developed different modal meanings.

Phonemic awareness of English second language learner background : the pa skill of phonological blending and segmentation and auditory worddiscrimination relate directly to literacy and may be weak in english second language (el2)learners. in south africa, literacy skill have been found to be poor in especially el2 learners.objectives : the purpose of this paper is to determine the effect of vowel perception andproduction intervention on phonemic awareness (pa) and literacy skill of setswana firstlanguage (l1) learners. these learner are english second language (el2) learner in grade 3.method : the present study employed a quasi-experimental, pre-test–post-test design.results : the finding of low–literacy skill level concurred with previous investigations.however, post-test result of intervention in pa seemed to improve the literacy skill of el2learners.conclusion : pa skill should be a crucial part of the literacy curriculum in south africa.

Language contact and linguistic change : the case of Afrikaans and English influence on isiNdebele adoption is an unavoidable type of linguistic behaviour that occurs when two or more language are in a state of contact with each other. adoption is the introduction of single word or short frozen phrase from one variety (i.e. language) into the other. adoption go together with adaptation. there are different level of adaptation, but this article focus on adoptives which are fully indigenised. a such they are incorporated into the grammatical system of the borrowing language, treated a part of it lexicon, assume it phonological and morphological characteristic and enter into it syntactic structures.  numerous study in african language have illustrated that lesser developed language have benefitted from the adoption of item from other languages. isindebele, a one of the lesser developed indigenous language of south africa, ha been in close contact with afrikaans and english for many year and ha adopted and adapted item from a number of word categories, such a nouns, verbs, adjectives, adverbs, relative and conjunctions. this article investigates and discus the adoption and adaptation of afrikaans and english word by isindebele. the discussion focus mainly on the various word category in afrikaans and english that isindebele ha adopted item from, lexicalisation of afrikaans phrase and the syntactic influence of afrikaans on isindebele.

Entre verbe et adverbe : Grammaticalisation et dégrammaticalisation du marqueur épistémique umeengo/umeenga en kirundi (bantou, JD62) la présente étude concerne l’évolution sémantique et formelle d’unadverbe épistémique du kirundi, umeengo/umeenga, le deux formes constituantdes variantes libres. elle est une de premières études s’inscrivant en linguistique decorpus pour le langues bantoues, une démarche rarement adoptée pour cettefamille de langues, de même qu’elle étudie une catégorie grammaticalegénéralement négligée dans le études linguistiques, c’est-à-dire l’adverbe. nousdécrivons le différents emplois de umeengo/umeenga : comme adverbe, maisaussi comme comparatif, et dans le emplois du verbe qui en émerge à l’étapesuivante dans son évolution. s origines sont éclairées par un indice retrouvé enkinyarwanda, langue proche du kirundi, ainsi que dans la variante dialectale dukirundi parlée à l’ouest du burundi, dans la région de l’imbo. d’après ce éléments,il apparaît que cet adverbe est formé par univerbation, plus précisément par fusiond’un verbe conjugué, umenya (du verbe -meny- « connaître ») et du quotatif ngo« que ». dans la suite du processus, à partir de cet adverbe épistémique, se forme unnouveau verbe, -meeng- « croire ; penser », différent de celui du départ, tant dans lesens qu’au niveau de la forme. une telle évolution au sein de l’adverbe, qui naît d’un verbe et débouche lui-même à la naissance d’un autre verbe, est rare dans leslangues du monde, de là l’intérêt de notre analyse. dans cette étude, nous nousinterrogeons sur la nature de processus à l’oeuvre. nous montrons que le changementsstructurels et sémantiques par lesquels l’adverbe umeengo/umeenga s’est formé sont à mettre sur le compte de la grammaticalisation. dans le même ordred’idée, nous analysons la formation du verbe -meeng- à partir de l’adverbe commele résultat d’une dégrammaticalisation.

A critical analysis of multilingual dictionary  this article evaluates the lexicographic value of multilingual dictionaries. dictionary covering three or more language spoken in south africa are taken a a case in point. an attempt will be made to reflect on their merit and shortcoming a reference work and learning tool but the focus will be on presumed shortcoming in the macro and micro structure of such dictionary with special attention to the lemmatisation of common words, quality of the dictionary article and consistency in presentation. in hierdie artikel word die leksikografiese waarde van veeltalige woordeboeke geëvalueer. woordeboeke wat drie of meer tale wat in suid-afrika gepraat word leksikografies bewerk, dien a voorbeeld. daar sal gepoog word om hulle sterk punte en tekortkominge a naslaanbronne en aanleerhulpmiddels te omskryf. klem sal gelê word op veronderstelde tekortkominge in die makro- en mikrostrukture van sulke woordeboeke met spesifieke verwysing na die lemmatisering van algemeen gebruikte woorde, kwaliteit van die woordeboekartikels en konsekwentheid in die aanbieding.

On the origin of the royal Kongo title ngangula  this article offer an in‑depth historical‑comparative linguistic account of the origin and etymology of ngangula. this term is not only a widespread blacksmith term in the lower congo region, but also a traditional royal kongo title attesting to the importance of the blacksmith metaphor in kongo political ideology. popular etymology ha it that ngangula is related to nganga, reconstructed in proto‑bantu a *-gàngà and commonly translated a ‘medicine-man’. it is argued here that this widely held belief doe not stand up to scrutiny. the term ngangula is shown to be derived from the common bantu verb *pàngʊd- meaning ‘to cut; to separate’. thanks to a distinctive diachronic sound change, it is even possible to locate quite precisely the term’s origin within the kikongo dialect continuum. it provenance give new credibility to an earlier but discarded hypothesis situating the origin of the kongo kingdom in the eastern part of the lower congo, somewhere in‑between the inkisi and kwango rivers. cet article offre une étude approfondie en linguistique historico-comparative sur l’origine et l’étymologie de ngangula. ce terme est non seulement répandu dans la région du bas-congo pour forgeron, mais c’est aussi un titre royal traditionnel kongo qui atteste de l’importance de la métaphore du forgeron dans l’idéologie politique kongo. l’étymologie populaire veut que le terme ngangula soit lié à nganga, reconstruit *-gàngà en proto-bantu et généralement traduit par ‘guérisseur’. nous montrons ici que cette croyance largement partagée ne résiste pa à un examen approfondi. nous montrons que le terme ngangula dérive plutôt du verbe *-pàngʊd‑ bien attesté en bantu et signifiant ‘couper, séparer’. à partir de l’évidence diachronique d’un changement phonétique distinctif, nous pouvons même situer assez précisément l’origine du terme au sein du continuum dialectal kikongo. sa source crédibilise à nouveau une hypothèse ancienne mais rejetée qui situait le origines du royaume kongo dans la partie orientale du bas-congo, quelque part entre le rivières inkisi et kwango.

A corpus-driven account of the noun class and gender in Northern Sotho this article offer a distributional corpus analysis of the northern sotho noun andgender system. the aim is twofold: first, to ass whether the existing description of the nounclass system in northern sotho are corroborated by information provided by the analysis of alarge electronic corpus for this language, with specific reference to singular-plural pairings, andsecond, to present a number of novel visualisation aid to characterise a noun class system (ina radar diagram) and a noun gender system (using a two-directional weighted representation)for northern sotho in particular, and for any bantu language in general. the finding include thediscovery of two new gender in northern sotho (i.e. class pair 1/6 and 3/10), and also indicatethat the northern sotho noun class system, and by extension any one for bantu, should be seenas dynamic.

Opgeroepte betekenis in literêre vertaling : die vertaling van dialek en register in Die swerfjare van Poppie Nongena deur Elsa Joubert  hierdie artikel behandel die oordrag van betekenis in literêre vertaling en lewer verslag oor  studie wat die vertaling van dialek en register in the long journey of poppie nongena (elsa joubert 1980), die engelse vertaling van die swerfjare van poppie nongena (1978), ondersoek het. die studie het aangetoon dat  literêre vertaling wat goed geskryf is en inhoudelik ooreenstem met die bronteks, steed onvoldoende mag wee indien alle vlakke van betekenis nie voldoende oorgedra is nie. betekenis sluit dus nie slegs die feitelike inhoud in nie. in literêre tekste is die wyse waarop inligting oorgedra word dikwels ewe belangrik a die inhoud, aangesien dit onder andere inligting verskaf oor die taalgebruikers en taalgebruikskontekste. in literêre vertaling word gebruikersverwante taalvariëteite (dialek) en gebruiksverwante taalvariëteite (register) dus tot  hoogs betekenisvolle vlak verhef. mona baker (1992) noem die betekenis wat uit dialek en register stam, "evoked meaning", of opgeroepte betekenis. die swerfjare van poppie nongena is in terme van opgeroepte betekenis swaar gelaai, maar die engelse vertaling toon nie dieselfde lading nie. die eerste doel van die artikel is om hierdie betekenisteenstrydigheid uit te wy deur middel van  vergelyking van die bron- en doelteks, en die tweede doel is om  meer gepaste strategie voor te stel. juliane house (1977, 1997, 2009) se teorie van waarneembare vertaling sal a oplossing bespreek en geïllustreer word deur gedeeltes van die teks wat volgens hierdie strategie in engels hervertaal is, voor te lê. só word die kulturele en sosiale karakterbehoud wat deur  verandering van vertaalstrategie bereik kan word, bewys. this article investigates the transfer of meaning in literary translation and present the finding of a recently concluded study (botha 2015). the article fulfils a two-fold purpose. the first is to prove that a literary translation may be well written and may reflect the content of the source text correctly, but may still be inadequate due to the fact that not all type of meaning have been translated adequately. this is proven by comparing elsa joubert renowned novel die swerfjare van poppie nongena (1978) with it english translation, the long journey of poppie nongena (1980), to demonstrate a significant shift in meaning due to an insufficient transfer of social dialect and informal register. the second purpose is to propose and illustrate a solution to the identified problem, which involves a discussion and an application by retranslation of juliane house (1977) strategy of overt translation, which entail a foreignisation of the translation in order to make the source culture and the situational context apparent. the retranslation illustrates an alternative translation strategy, but doe not suggest that this is "the ultimate" alternative. it is simply one which seek to retain a crucial aspect of the source text and is also open to critiquing and alteration.

Genome-wide analysis of gene expression during adipogenesis in human adipose-derived stromal cell reveals novel pattern of gene expression during adipocyte differentiation we have undertaken an in-depth transcriptome analysis of adipogenesis in human adipose-derived stromal cell (ascs) induced to differentiate into adipocytes in vitro. gene expression wa assessed on day 1, 7, 14 and 21 post-induction and gene differentially expressed numbered 128, 218, 253 and 240 respectively. up-regulated gene were associated with blood vessel development, leukocyte migration, a well a tumor growth, invasion and metastasis. they also shared common pathway with certain obesity-related pathophysiological conditions. down-regulated gene were enriched for immune response processes. klf15, lmo3, foxo1 and zbtb16 transcription factor were up-regulated throughout the differentiation process. cebpa, pparg, znf117, mlxipl, mmp3 and rorb were up-regulated only on day 14 and 21, which coincide with the maturation of adipocytes and could possibly serve a candidate for controlling fat accumulation and the size of mature adipocytes. in summary, we have identified gene that were up-regulated only on day 1 and 7 or day 14 and 21 that could serve a potential early and late-stage differentiation markers.

Cattle and their colour : a synchronic investigation of cattle colour terminology in Northern Sotho in northern sotho, a separate colour lexicon is distinguished, containing term which are believed to be usedexclusively a colour term to describe not only the colours, but also the colour patterning found among domesticanimals, particularly cattle. according to current literature, the use of these term is restricted to the description ofcattle and/or other domestic animals. this study, which is corpus-based, investigates the metaphorical extension ofthese term which widens their descriptive scope to include object other than cattle. it is furthermore argued thatthese term have unique grammatical features, found nowhere else in the grammatical system of northern sotho.lastly, the metaphoric link between these colour and colour-pattern term and similar sounding word designatingother animals, bird or everyday object is investigated. it is concluded that this particular colour lexicon is of anambivalent nature: on the one hand it is an indigenous knowledge system which is clearly in decline, mostly dueto non-linguistic factors, but simultaneously, it ability to be extended to the description of other object pointstowards a certain measure of vitality.

Implementation of a part-of-speech ontology : morphemic unit of Bantu language in a previous article (faaß et al, 2012), a first attempt wa made at documenting andencoding morphemic unit of two south african bantu languages, i.e. northern sotho and zulu, withthe aim of describing and storing the morphemic unit of these two language in a single relationaldatabase, structured a a hierarchical ontology. a a follow-up, the current article describes theimplementation of our part-of-speech ontology. we give a detailed description of the morpheme andcategories contained in the database, highlighting the need and reason for a flexible ontology whichwill provide for both language specific and general linguistic information. by giving a detailedaccount of the methodology for the population of the database, we provide linguist from other bantulanguages with a road map for extending the database to also include their language of specialization.

The elusive archaeology of Kongo urbanism : the case of Kindoki, Mbanza Nsundi (Lower Congo, DRC)  we present results, analyses, and an in-depth historical contextualizationof the fieldwork undertaken in 2012 and 2013 at the kindoki site in thelower congo (drc). this site is linked to mbanza nsundi, one of the kongokingdom’s provincial capitals, which turn out to be archaeologically ‘elusive’.pinpointing it location proved to be particularly challenging. to this end, ahistorically informed survey methodology wa applied that ha rarely beenimplemented on such a scale in central africa before. we combined a strategy of systematic test pit with a large-scale 50-m grid approach. a cemetery wa identifiedon kindoki hill with distinct but probably contemporaneous quarter of a sixteenth–seventeenth-century settlement on both sides. the cemetery itself contains mainlyeighteenth-century burials, in all likelihood of successive high-ranking nsundi nobles,perhaps even of nsundi rulers. the foreign, especially portuguese, ceramic excavatedon the hilltop and the hundred of venetian and likely bavarian bead found in thegraves are indicative ofmbanza nsundi’s connection to trade route linking the atlanticcoast with the pool region. the most striking discovery is that of a previously unknowntype of comb-impressed pottery, from a pit with a calibrated radiocarbon date of ad1294–1393 (at 2 sigma). this suggests that a settlement had been developing at kindokisince at least the fourteenth century, which allows us, for the first time, to spatially bridgekongo history and “prehistory.” for the entire lower congo region, only three 14cdatesposterior to ad 1000 were available before the start of our project; 12 have been addedfor just kindoki. nous présentons le résultats, le analysis et la contextualisation historiquedétaillée du travail de terrain entrepris en 2012 et 2013 sur le site de kindoki situé aubas-congo (rdc). ce site est associé à mbanza nsundi, l’une de capitalesprovinciales du royaume kongo, qui s’est révélée ‘élusive’, c-à-d difficile à saisirarchéologiquement. localiser son emplacement s’est avéré être un vrai défi. pour cefaire, nous avon développé une méthodologie de fouilles, basée sur de donnéeshistoriques, qui n’avait pa encore vraiment été testée à cette échelle en afriquecentrale. nous avon appliqué une stratégie de terrain combinant de tranchées testssystématiques avec de carroyages à grande échelle de 50 m. sur la colline de kindoki,un cimetière a été identifié avec de part et d’autre de quartiers distincts, probablementcontemporains, témoignant d’une occupation aux 16ème-17ème siècles. le cimetière luimêmecontient principalement de inhumation successives datées du 18ème siècle, trèsprobablement celles de et probablement de la bavière trouvées dans le tombes révèlent la connexion entre mbanza nsundi etles voies commerciales reliant la côte atlantique avec la région du pool. unedécouverte très intéressante concerne un type de poterie décorée au peigne impriméqui était inconnu à ce jour et provient d’une fosse dont la date radiocarbone calibrée estde 1294–1393 ad (à 2 sigma). ceci suggère bas-congo toute entière, seules trois date 14c postérieures à 1000 ad étaient disponiblesavant que ne débute notre projet. nous disposons à présent de douze datessupplémentaires uniquement pour le site de kindoki.

Mongwalelo wa sefela sa Serote : ‘a re thabeng re rete’ (Difela tša kereke, 2010)  bangwadi ba bathobaso ba difela tša kereke ba hueditšwe ke bangwadi ba baruti (bamatoitšhi ba kereke ya lutere ya berlin) ge ba tlo ngwala difela. ka go realo ke ba mathomoba go ngwala poleloopelwa ya sepedi. ka lebaka la gore baruti ba matoitšhi ba be ba satsebe melao ya go laola metara wa sepedi, ba thomile go hlama difela tša bona ka mokgwawo difela tša setoitšhi di hlamilwego ka wona. bangwadi ba difela ba bapedi le bona baba šala morago bjalo. ka go realo go ka thwe mothopomogolo wa khuetšo ya sebjalebjaledingwalong tša sepedi ke mediro ya kereke ya mathomothomo. le ge go le bjalo bohlokwabjo bja kgolo ya theto ka tsela ya difela dingwalong tša sepedi ga se bja šalwa morago le gogatelelwa ke basekaseki. maikemišetšo a taodišwana ye ke go lekola, ka botlalo, mongwalelowa difela ka go nepiša sefela sa serote sa 147 sa go bitšwa ‘a re thabeng re rete’ (difela tšakereke 2010:130). go yo tsitsinkela ka fao mongwalelo o tšwetšago pele kgegeo. ka mantšu amangwe, go yo sekasekwa dipharologantšho tša mongwalelo tše di tšwetšago pele kgegeo.go tlo lemogwa gore kgegeo yeo e bonagatšwa ka modiro wa selalelo se sekgethwa samorena seo se hlalošwago ka tsela ya khuduego/maikutlo go tšwetša pele morero wamongwadi/moopedi wa sefela se ka ge bjale selalelo e le selo seo bakriste ba se hlomphago(se lebane le tshwarelo ya dibe tša bona), go ya ka fao se hlalošwago ka gona ka tsela yeoya kgegeo. black composer of church hymn were influenced by german pastor of the berlinlutheran church to do so. in other words, these pastor were the first composer towrite the sepedi language in the form of music; because they did not know the rulesthat control the sepedi meter, the writer started to compose their hymn in the way thatthe german hymn were patterned. therefore, one might argue that the main source ofmodern influence in sepedi literature lie in the working of the very first hymn of thesaid church. nevertheless, the importance of the development of poetry in the form ofhymns in the sepedi literature ha not been followed up and emphasised by reviewers.the aim of this article is to survey thoroughly the style of writing hymns, by discussingrev serote’s hymn number 147, entitled ‘a re thabeng re rete’ (difela tša kereke 2010:130).the scrutiny will examine the way in which style depicts irony in the very hymn. in otherwords, the investigation considers especially the characteristic of style that indicate anddevelop irony in the work. it will be shown that the irony becomes clear during the serviceof baptism which is expressed by way of emotion to develop the author’s aim, a thissacrament is something that christian respect (it go hand in hand with the forgivenessof their sins).

On the most innovative outer access structure of any Bantu dictionary : the Lexique kikongo-francais by Charles Polis (1938)  in this article a little-known dictionary manuscript from the 1930s, the lexique kikongo-français by the jesuit missionary charles polis, is analysed in great detail. section 1 expounds on the goal and raison d'être of the study, section 2 introduces the manuscript, it author a well a the kikongo variety dealt with, section 3 present the inner working of the lexique on macro-, micro- and mediostructural levels, section 4 give a lexicographical appreciation based on a large selection of the entries, section 5 join the international debate on the exact nature of a dictionary macro-structure, access structure and access route, and section 6 compare polis work with a dictionary from the same region and period. conclusion are offered in section 7, chief among them the fact that polis designed the most innovative outer access structure of any bantu dictionary. artikel wordt een weinig bekend woordenboekmanuscript uit de jaren 1930, het lexicon kikongo–frans van de jezuïet-missionaris charles polis, in detail onderzocht. deel 1 licht het doel en de bestaansre-den van de studie toe, deel 2 introduceert het manuscript, zijn auteur, alsook de behandelde variant, deel 3 beschrijft minutieus de macro-, micro- en mediostructuur van het lexicon, deel 4 geeft een lexi-cografische appreciatie die is gebaseerd op een ruime selectie van materiaal uit het werk, deel 5 draagt bij tot het internationale debat over de ware aard van de macrostructuur, toegangstructuur en toegangsroute van een woordenboek, en deel 6 vergelijkt polis' werk met een woordenboek uit dezelfde regio en tijd. conclusies worden aangeboden in deel 7, de belangrijkste het feit dat polis de meest innovatieve externe toegangstructuur uit de bantoelexicografie ontwierp.

Corpus-based lexicography for lesser-resourced language - maximizing the limited corpus  this article focus on lesser-resourced language for which only very limited corpus are available and how such relatively small and often unbalanced, raw corpus could be maximally utilized for lexicographic purpose to obtain similar result a for bigger corpora. sepedi and afri-kaans will be studied in this regard. the aim is to determine to what extent enlarging a corpus from e.g. one to 10 million, and from 10 million to 100 million word enhances it potential for (a) macro-structure compilation, (b) sourcing information on the most important microstructural aspect and (c) the creation of lexicographic tools. it will be argued that valuable and even sufficient data for the compilation of a specific dictionary can be extracted from a relatively small corpus of approxi-mately one million word but that "bigger" in some instance indeed mean "better". die fokus in hierdie artikel is op hulp-bronbeperkte tale waarvoor slegs baie beperkte korpusse beskikbaar is en hoe sodanige relatief klein en dikwels ongebalanseerde, rou korpusse maksimaal benut kan word vir leksikografiese doeleindes om soortgelyke resultate a van groter korpusse te verkry. sepedi en afrikaans, word in hierdie verband bestudeer. die doel is om te bepaal tot watter mate die vergroting van  korpus van byvoorbeeld een na 10 miljoen, en van 10 miljoen na 100 miljoen woorde die potensiaal sal ver-hoog vir (a) makrostruktuur samestelling, (b) die inwin van inligting omtrent die belangrikste mikrostrukturele aspekte en (c) die ontwerp van leksikografiese hulpmiddels. daar sal aangevoer word dat waardevolle en self voldoende data vir die samestelling van  spesifieke woordeboek onttrek kan word uit  relatief klein korpus van ongeveer een miljoen woorde maar dat "groter" wel in sekere omstandighede "beter" is.

Collocations and grammatical pattern in a multilingual online term bank  this article considers the importance of including various type of collocation in a terminological database, with the aim of making this information available to the user via the user interface. we refer specifically to the inclusion of empirical and phraseological collocations, and information on grammatical patterning. attention is also given to provision of information on semantic prosody and semantic preference — aspect which have been rather neglected in south african terminological databanks and language for special purpose (lsp) dictionaries. various strategy for the effective semi-automatic extraction of collocational data from specialized corpus are explored. possibility regarding access to and presentation of collocational information to the user are briefly considered. it is argued that user should have direct access to collocational infor-mation, and that collocation should not only be accessible via the lemmatic address of the term appearing a part of the collocation. the research is done within the context of the establishment of an open access resource term bank, which is developed a a pedagogical tool to support student whose language of learning and teaching is not the l1. hierdie artikel ondersoek die belangrikheid van die insluiting van verskillende tipes kollokatiewe inligting in  veeltalige terminologiese databank met die oog daarop om hierdie inligting aan die gebruiker via die gebruikerskoppelvlak beskikbaar te stel. ons verwys spesifiek na die Event-centrality and the pragmatics–semantics interface in Kikongo : from predication focus to progressive aspect and vice versa across bantu, several polysemic marker expressing progressiveaspect and so-called predication focus have been reported (güldemann 2003;hyman and watters 1984). in this article, we examine two such marker inkikongo (bantu, h16), i.e. the fronted-infinitive and the locative-infinitive constructions.we provide an in-depth synchronic description of the pragmatic andsyntactic behaviour of both verbal construction and suggest a historical evolutionfor each of them. we evoke the term ‘event-centrality’ to cover the differentuses of both construction and suggest that the fronted-infinitive construction’sprogressive meaning evolved from it use a predication focus marker, and viceversa, that the locative-infinitive construction’s predication focus meaningevolved from it use a a progressive marker.

Linguistic innovation, political centralization and economic integration in the Kongo kingdom : reconstructing the spread of prefix reduction in this article we reconstruct the actuation and transmission of a phonologicalinnovation known a prefix reduction within the kikongo language clustersituated in the wider lower congo region of central africa. we argue that thischange spread from a focal area coinciding with the heartland of the kongokingdom a a classical process of dialectal diffusion. thanks to a unique kikongocorpus that start in the 17th century, we can provide diachronic empiricalevidence for different phase of the process, which ha been otherwise difficult,if not impossible, in bantu historical linguistics. what is more, and also quiteexceptional in african linguistics, we have fairly good insight into the ‘socialecology’ of this language change and argue that political centralization andeconomic integration within the realm of the kongo kingdom facilitated such acontact-induced diffusion between closely-related language varieties.

Archaeological research on the Kongo kingdom in the Lower Congo region of Central Africa the kongo kingdom, which arose in central africa’s atlantic coast region, is an emblem ofafrica’s past and an important cultural landmark for african and the african diaspora(figure 1). a a result of it early involvement in the trans-atlantic trade and it earlyintroduction to literacy, the history of this part of sub-saharan africa from ad 1500 onwardsis better known than most other part of the continent. nonetheless, still very little isunderstood about the origin of the kingdom.

African-European contact in the Kongo kingdom (sixteenth-eighteenth centuries) : new archaeological insight from Ngongo Mbata (lower Congo, DRC) ngongo mbata, the main and most affluent center of the kongo kingdom’smbata province in the seventeenth century, is well known from the historical sources, but virtually unexplored in archaeological publications. ngongo mbata is unique in that ithosted a monumental stone building about which the historical record remains silent. thismakes it particularly challenging from the point of view of historical archaeology. in thispaper historical data, unpublished excavation result from the 1930s and our ownfieldwork undertaken in 2012–13 are brought together, to tell a new story of earlyafrican-european contact in the interior of west central africa.

Dictionary user in the digital revolution this contribution examines the digital revolution in lexicography from the perspectiveof the dictionary user. we begin with an observation that in the information age thestatus of the dictionary is changing, and so are pattern of user behaviour, with generalinternet search engine encroaching on the ground traditionally reserved for lexicographicqueries. clearly, we need to know more about user behaviour in the digitalenvironment, and for this we need to harness user research, to find out how the increasinglyflexible and adaptive lexical reference tool of the future need to behave to bestaccommodate user needs. we summarize the existing finding and show in what waysdigital dictionary are already able to serve user better than their paper predecessors.the challenge to produce efficient and effective dictionary is best seen in the contextof dictionary users’ reference skills, which now tend to overlap with digital literacy.we conclude with a possible vision of the future.

Diachronic semantics of the modal verb -sóból- in Luganda : a corpus-driven approach in this article the semantic evolution of the modal verb -sóból- in luganda isexamined through the analysis of a diachronic corpus spanning the last 120years. it is shown that the usage frequency of this verb increased exponentiallybetween the early 20th century and the present, and that it use a a lexical verbhas dramatically decreased during the same time span. the corpus data furthermoresubstantiate that it modal us have been extended from the exclusiveexpression of dynamic possibility until the 1960s to deontic possibility. methodologically,this is the first full-scale article within the young field of bantucorpus linguistics in which a corpus-driven study is performed on a diachroniccorpus. the approach is not only shown to be feasible, but the encouragingresults will hopefully entice colleague working on the bantu language toundertake the building and analysis of such diachronic corpus for linguisticpurposes.

Towards a part-of-speech ontology : encoding morphemic unit of two South African Bantu language this article describes the design of an electronic knowledge base, namely a morpho-syntacticdatabase structured a an ontology of linguistic categories, containing linguistic unit of tworelated language of the south african bantu group: northern sotho and zulu. theselanguages differ significantly in their surface orthographies, but are very similar on the lexicaland sub-lexical levels. it is therefore our goal to describe the morpheme of these language ina single common database in order to outline and interpret commonality and difference inmore detail. moreover, the relational database which is developed defines the underlyingmorphemic unit (morphs) for both languages. it will be shown that the electronic part-ofspeechontology go hand in hand with part-of-speech tagsets that label morphemic units.this database is designed a part of a forthcoming system providing lexicographic andlinguistic knowledge on the official south african bantu languages.

In search of larger unit of meaning: a foray into Northern Sotho data the availability of large-scale electronic language corpus ha led to revolutionarychanges in the landscape of linguistic research. corpus linguistics ha in the pastfew decade developed from an alternative methodology of linguistic investigation toa fully-fledged theoretical approach to linguistic study. furthermore, having access toelectronic corpus ha lead scholar such a sinclair (2004) to redefine the basic unitof meaning of language. in the light of corpus evidence, he proposes the existence of alexical unit which represents a lexical structure higher than the word, in which meaningis vested. in this article, the notion of a functional unit of meaning in northern sothois explored. two case study are presented, illustrating not only the methodology ofcorpus-driven investigation for a bantu language, but also the theoretical and practicalimplications of recognising the existence of extended unit of meaning.

When chaos is the god of an era : rediscovering an Axis Mundi in Ben Okri’s Starbook (2007) the article begin by contextualizing ben okri’s concept of reality within atraditional, cultural framework. a brief discussion of the trajectory of african writingand the standard classification of the mode of the okri oeuvre a either non-realist ormagical realism follows. the argument challenge both appellation in reference tomy recent interview of the author (16 february 2011) in which okri redefines ‘reality’in term of the full keyboard of life. the stance, ultimately, eschews classification of aparadise lost and regained, thus avoiding any classification that might contradict themercurial unfoldment of the spirit in starbook (2007). this article proceeds to providethe rationale for the title chosen by quoting from both okri’s star of the new curfew(1988) and starbook (2007), and by linking the idea of chaos and consolation asintegral to enlightenment. short discussion on cosmic consciousness, transpersonalexperience, the sublime, the myth of eternal return and what is understood by an axismundi follow – drawing principally on mircea eliade and gerald larue and showinghow these concept can be applied to a reading of okri’s eleventh prose work.

Corpus-based language teaching : an African language perspective study on corpus-based language teaching are notably absent within the southafrican educational context; more so with regard to the teaching of africanlanguages. this article explores the possibility offered by the availability of anelectronic corpus to enhance language teaching, and more specifically, the teaching ofnorthern sotho a a second additional language at first year university level to firsttime learner of the language. particular attention is paid to corpus-based selectionand sequencing of learning material, an activity that ha hitherto depended onanecdotal evidence and the intuition of the language teacher. a critical evaluation ofexisting pedagogical material for northern sotho reveals that although excellentsources of reference, these work are inadequate for the purpose of teaching northernsotho to first time learners. it is indicated that information gleaned from a corpusprovides the language teacher with guidance on both micro and macro level withregard to selection and sequencing of learning content.

Leksikografiese bewerking van verwantskapsterme in Sepedi  die verwantskapsterminologie van sepedi is omvangryk en vorm  komplekse sisteem. in teenstelling met tale soos afrikaans, engels en duits A computational implementation of the Northern Sotho infinitive the aim of this article is to describe the infinitive in northern sotho based on corpus data and therespective literature; so far, all share the same view: the infinitive is a noun (of class 15) and a verb atthe same time – ‘it manifest both nominal a well a verbal features’ (poulos & louwrens, 1994:42).when implementing these constellation in a parser, however, a new perspective is found: to achieveits successful implementation, the infinitive must be defined a a verb on the one hand and a a noun ofclass 15 on the other, derived from this verb through nominalization (transposition). instead of a subjectconcord, the verb stem in the infinitive is preceded by the respective class prefix.

Use of LSP dictionary in secondary school - a South African case study this article report on the result of a broad evaluation of the efficacy of the multilingual explanatoryscience dictionary and multilingual explanatory math dictionary in a multilingual educationalenvironment. the aim of the investigation is to ascertain (a) whether the target user posse the necessarydictionary using skill to make use of the dictionary effectively, and (b) whether the benefit of exposureto definition of term in the home language is significant in the decoding of the meaning of scienceand mathematical terms. data were collected by mean of two questionnaire that were completed bymembers of the intended target user group. participant in the study revealed themselves inexperiencedand untrained dictionary user with rudimentary dictionary using skills. they were able to perform simplelook-up procedure but performed badly in case where a more sophisticated approach is called for.

Bilingual dictionary for a specific user group : supporting Setswana speaker in the production and reception of English the aim of this article is to discus the design of a new english to setswana dictionary for two narrowlydefined target user group of setswana learners, i.e. upper primary (10 to 12 year old); and juniorsecondary (13 to 15 year old). the dictionary is intended to be a guide to text and speech productionin the foreign language l2 (english) and the reception of english text and speech in l1 (setswana). ageneral consideration concern the relationship between the treatment of english and that of setswana.as english is to be treated a a priority, many more data type will be made available for english thanfor setswana. furthermore, we will ass the possibility of producing a bilingual learners’ dictionarywith rather imbalanced parts: for production in (and translation into) english, a detailed descriptionof individual item is needed, whereas for reception (and translation) from english, a large list oftreatment unit is necessary, albeit with le elaborate descriptive detail. the design also aim at strongguidance through the mother tongue, setswana. two possible scenario are considered, namely separatedictionaries for the two target group or a single dictionary to serve the lexicographic need of bothtarget groups. socio-economic circumstance of most of the learner are such that buying more than onedictionary is not a realistic option, and they find themselves in a pre-dictionary culture with the resultantlack of dictionary using skills. the dictionary/dictionaries will be for paper dictionaries. the focus is onbilingualized (bld) and extended bilingual (ebl) dictionary a basic design options. we envisage animbalanced design where guidance in term of both production and reception is focused on english. ourdesign aim at the maximum utilization of the physical space in a paper dictionary with coverage of atleast 90% of both english and setswana.

Lekgothoane's praise poetry : an aesthetic discourse in this article, shika kgomedi lekgothoane artistic poetic work collected in ‘praises of animal innorthern sotho’ (van warmelo, 1937) are assessed on three parts: a biographical sketch, a text anda reader in order to give a map to negotiate his creative skills. lekgothoane is a traditional praisepoet. his praise poetry fall within the delimitation of nature, which is not associated with leadershipas is expected in this type of poetic work. the article proposes that nature a recited by him, enablesthe reader to understand fully the whole universe including it living thing (animals). this indicatesthat lekgothoane environment is the place where cultural and traditional behaviour, custom andhumanity are taught. his poem thus evoke a spirit of nationality.

The (Ama)Ndebele of Africa and their name '(ama)Ndebele' some scholar still continue to confuse or to misunderstand the relationship within the (ama)ndebeleof africa a a result of the divergent opinion propounded by scholar regarding the historical originthese ethnic groups. first, historians, anthropologist and linguist such a fourie (1921), vanwarmelo (1930), van vuuren (1983) and others regard the (ama)ndebele of the republic of southafrica (which are divided into southern and northern (ama)ndebele) to be historically related. othersregard them a distinct ethnic groups. secondly, while some consider the south african(ama)ndebele and those of zimbabwe to be distinct from each other, others regard them a related.what make matter more confusing regarding the relationship of these (ama)ndebele ethnic groupsof africa, is the fact that they share the same ethnic name ‘(ama)ndebele’ and the same language‘isindebele’.the aim of this article is, therefore, twofold a) to investigate and discus the historical background of(ama)ndebele found within the border of the republic of south africa and those of zimbabwe and b)to examine and discus the origin of the ethnic name ‘ndebele’ or ‘amandebele’. the name‘amandebele’ or simply ‘ndebele’ is a generic name used to refer to the nguni group found in andoutside the border of the republic of south africa. the historical origin of the name ‘(ama)ndebele’is also re-visited, evaluated and discussed. in conclusion, the article show that the (ama)ndebelepeople of the republic of africa (i.e., southern and northern (ama)ndebele) are historically relatedbut neither is related to those of zimbabwe despite the fact that they share the same ethnic name‘(ama)ndebele’ and the same language ‘(isindebele)’.
