geraadpleeg. die datatipe waaraan die gemiddelde en kundige gebruiker van tweetalige woordeboeke die grootste behoefte het en wat daarom die algemeenste teiken van woordeboekraadpleging is, is die vertaalekwivalente, dit is die doeltaalvorme wat vir  bepaalde brontaalvorm verskaf word. die leksikograaf moet vir drie hooftipes ekwivalentverhoudinge voorsiening maak, te wete absolute ekwivalensie, gedeeltelike ekwivalensie en zero-ekwivalensie. dit is veral gevalle van zeroekwivalensie wat leksikograwe voor die uitdaging stel om op verskillende maniere daarvoor voorsiening te maak dat die gebruikers  optimale onttrekking van inligting aan woordeboekartikels behaal. in hierdie artikel word gefokus op die aard en besondere omvang van zeroekwivalensie in die afrikatale en word verskillende tipes surrogaatekwivalente en benaderingswyses onder die loep geneem.  onderskeid word ook gemaak tussen verskillende vlakke van surrogaatekwivalensie. die benadering is kontemplatief sowel a transformatief en die behoeftes van die teikengebruikers ten opsigte van teksresepsie en teksproduksie word vooropgestel. the focus in a general bilingual dictionary is on the item presenting translation equivalent for the word represented by the lemma signs. three major type of equivalent relation prevail, i.e. full equivalence, partial equivalence and zero equivalence. these different relation of equivalence confront lexicographer with different challenge to ensure that the user will be able to achieve an optimal retrieval of information from a given dictionary article. ideally, suitable translation equivalent in the target language would be available for each source language item. instance where a suitable translation equivalent is not available occur in any given language pair to be treated a source and target. adamska-sałaciak (2006:99) go a far a to state that "due to interlingual anisomorphism a bilingual dictionary is, strictly speaking, an impossibility" and that "all we can hope to produce are better or worse approximations". lexicographer have an obligation towards their specific user to ensure a presentation and treatment of translation equivalent that will enable an unambiguous retrieval of information from the data on offer in the comment on semantics of a bilingual dictionary. the nature and extent of this treatment should be determined by the need and reference skill of the intended target user group, the user situation and the lexicographic function of the specific dictionary. there are frequent instance in any given language pair where a suitable translation equivalent is not available to be treated a source and target language in a bilingual dictionary. this is known a zero equivalence and can be regarded a the most complex type of equivalence to be dealt with in a bilingual dictionary. a linguistic gap can be identified when the speaker of both language are familiar with a certain concept, but when one language doe not have a word to refer to it, whereas the other language doe have such a word. a referential gap can be postulated when a lexical item from language a ha no translation equivalent in language b. this would be because the speaker of language b do not know the referent of the lexical item from language a. this article address the various way in which lexicographer of different dictionary deal with the lack of equivalence and the subsequent use of surrogate equivalents. there are a number of strategy that the lexicographer can use when dealing with instance of zero equivalence, e.g. the use of glosses, paraphrases, illustration and even text box with lexicographic comments. this article suggests different type of surrogate equivalent based on user needs, and it will be done in accordance with the relevant dictionary functions, i.e. the cognitive function and the communicative function of text reception, text production and translation. it will be indicated that lexicographic treatment of zero equivalence is a major factor in bilingual dictionary bridging, for example, afrikaans or english with african languages. in many case a substantial part, even a large number of sequential lemma in any given alphabetical stretch, comprise zero equivalence. such instances, mostly in respect of cultural term pose a great challenge to the lexicographer. they vary in nature and complexity and call for different and innovative way of lexicographic treatment. in this article the focus will be on the nature and extent of zero equivalence in the african languages, and different type of surrogate equivalent form the basis of the discussion. a distinction will also be made between different level of surrogate equivalence. the approach is contemplative a well a transformative, with the emphasis on the need of target user in respect of text reception and text production. acknowledging different degree of complexity in the relation of surrogate equivalence lead to a tiered view of the concept. the first level in the hierarchy provides for linguistic gap where a mere gloss or brief paraphrase of meaning will suffice. more complicated are the gap where the surrogate equivalent also ha to provide grammatical guidance. the top tier in the hierarchy provides for referential gap where taboo, culture-specific or sensitive value have to be expressed. the lexicographer ha to utilise available treatment option maximally and select the mostappropriate one(s) in each case.

Querying the claim of the user-friendliness of the New Sepedi Dictionary the new sepedi dictionary is a concisetranslating bilingual dictionary. even thoughthe compiler claim that this dictionary is very user-friendly, this can be queried. accordingly, the main aim of this article is to test the usefulness of this lexicographic compilation. the discussion is restricted to the english–sepedi part a sepedi is the target language. a study of the dictionary articles, spelling, unnecessaryloanwords, corresponding words, coinages, hyphenated words, repetition of word and inconsistency display the deficiency in this dictionary. a a result, it is recommended that the dictionary should be duly revisited and revised.

Designing a noun guesser for part of speech tagging in Northern Sotho in this article, we describe an element of a suite of computational tool for assigning word-class tag (as a preparation for part of speech (pos) tagging) to word form in unrestricted northern sotho texts. pos-tagging is a step towards a linguistic analysis of the texts, which in turn allows for advanced data extraction.the tool component that is described, identifies (and classifies) noun forms. several type of linguistic knowledge are used to recognize noun that are not contained in the noun lexicon of the system. these include the relationship between singular and plural noun prefixes, knowledge about noun derivation, and data about the co-occurrence of the candidate with concords, pronoun and adjective in a local context.our implementation is a symbolic, voting-based process : together, all test determine whether a candidate is a noun; accuracy on unseen test data is around 92%.

Divination expressed through poetry : the divinatory poem of Johannes Mokgwadi this article aim to explore the divinatory poem of johannes mokgwadi with special reference to their structure, role and tool of performance in the art of divination a practised still today by the bapedi in some rural area of south africa. cultural verse form in 'the poetry of divinatory bones', a this form of poetry may be called (due to the set of divinatory bone used in the process of divination), will be outlined through a discussion of metrical compositions, long-measure verse, long-measure 'echo' or repetition verse, divinatory poem with linked hemistichs, divinatory poem with repeated segments, long-measure triplet verse, and verse of four, five or more hemistichs. these form design are intended to achieve maximum impact when recited. the role of the traditional healer a an intermediary figure between the god and his people will be indicated. divinatory poem are shrouded in secrecy, a they are intended for listening (by targeted addressees) and not for reading (by the general public), for communication with ancestor and not for performance before an audience in public gatherings. the discussion of the divinatory apparatus serf to shed light on the symbolism of the key icon in the selected extract from the poetry.

characterisation of female include oppression and ill-treatment, discrimination and segregation, ignorance, physical violence against female and limitation of the role of woman to caring for the extended family. in the experimental phase, feature include liberation of a female character, freedom of the whole society, agreement on marriage and working together a a team to solve the problem of society. the phase of feminism is identified by feature of characterisation of female such a eradication of oppression, the fight for equality between woman and men, removal of segregation and On the development of a tagset for Northern Sotho with special reference to the issue of standardisation  working with corpus in the south african bantu language ha up till now been limited to the utilisation of raw corpora. such corpora, however, have limited functionality. thus the next logical step in any nlp application is the development of software for automatic tagging of electronic texts. the development of a tagset is one of the first step in corpus annotation. the author of this article argue that the design of a tagset cannot be isolated from the purpose of the tagset, or from the place of the tagset and it design within the bigger picture of the architecture of corpus annotation. usage-related aspect therefore feature prominently in the design of the tagset for northern sotho. it is explained why this proposed tagset is biased towards human readability, rather than machine readability; this choice of a stochastic tagger is motivated, and the relationship between tokenising, tagging, morphological analysis and parsing is discussed. in order to account at least to some extent for the morphological complexity of northern sotho at the tagging level, a multilevel annotation is opted for: the first level comprising obligatory information and the second optional and recommended  information. finally, aspect of standardisation are considered against the background of reuse, of sharing of resources, and of possible adaptation for use by other disjunctively written south african bantu languages. it is not the aim of this article to evaluate the result of any tagging procedure using the proposed tagset. it only describes the design and motivates the choice made with regard to the tagset design. however, an evaluation is in process and result will be published in the near future (cf. faasz et al., s.a.) tot dusver wa die gebruik van korpora in die suid-afrikaanse bantoetale beperk tot die ontginning van rou korpora. die gebruiksmoontlikhede van hierdie tipe korpora is egter beperk. die volgende logiese stap in enige toepassing van natuurlike taalprosessering is dus die ontwikkeling van sagteware vir outomatiese teksannotering. die ontwikkeling van ’n stel annoteringsmerkers is een van die eerste stappe in korpus-annotering. die outeurs van hierdie artikel meen dat die ontwerp van ’n annoteringstel direk verband hou met die doel van so ’n stel, en die posisie daarvan binne die groter raamwerk van die argitektuur van korpusannotasie. gebruiksaspekte staan daarom sentraal in die ontwerp van ’n annoteringstel vir noord-sotho. daar word verduidelik waarom hierdie stel eerder vir menslike leesbaarheid a vir masjienleesbaarheid voorsiening maak; Mystery in Sepedi detective story the aim of this article is to illustrate the importance of the concept "mystery" in the classification of sepedi detective stories. mystery is therefore first defined, and then some rule governing how mystery is created and sustained in a narrative are reviewed. example are given of how the writer of sepedi detective story mislead their reader in order to create mystery. mystery is then examined according to five of it constituent elements, namely the real character of the detective, the name of the criminal, the identity of the victim, the evidence that reveals the mystery in the end, and the investigation that reveals the mystery. each category is explored by citing relevant example from sepedi detective stories. afrikaans: die doel van hierdie artikel is om die belangrikheid van die konsep "raaisel" in die klassifikasie van sepedi speurverhale te illustreer. die raaisel word eers gedefinieer en daarna word  oorsig gegee van die reëls wat die skep en voortbou van die raaisel onderlê. voorbeelde word verskaf van hoe sepedi-speurverhaalskrywers lesers doelbewus mislei om daardeur raaisels te skep. die raaisel word vervolgens bestudeer aan die hand van vyf onderliggende elemente, naamlik die ware karakter van die speurder, die naam van die misdadiger, die identiteit van die slagoffer, die bewyse wat daartoe lei dat die raaisel aan die einde ontrafel word en die ondersoek wat die raaisel aan die lig bring. elke kategorie word ondersoek deur die verwysing na gepaste voorbeelde uit sepedi-speurverhale.

Child abuse in Setswana folktale this article examines the possible role played by african folk literature, taking setswana folktale a a case in point, in justifying and perpetuating the abusive behaviour so often witnessed and decried in postmodern society. we found some evidence that certain folktale may depict real-life child abuse by adult (male and female), and, indeed, serve to perpetuate pre-modern societal beliefs. ideally speaking, citizen should probably be educated about the possible negative impact of that part of folk literature that serf to perpetuate negative stereotype of child a object to be (ab)used. since folk literature may be serving a a potentially significant guardian of these beliefs, a possible first step would be to identify folktale and other story that may keep alive belief that reinforce obsolete view about children. this is a challenge to all folklorists.
